If the minister in his decision endorses a master plan which contains within it a recommendation for a parallel runway, it follows that in the major development plan the Brisbane Airport Corporation would not be required to test and examine and advance non-parallel runway alternatives. Therefore, my challenge to the minister is very simple. Given this provision of the act, if he proceeds by or on 23 February to endorse this master plan, will he require the Brisbane Airport Corporation explicitly to examine fully all alternative runway options, so that when the major development plan is put back to the minister for final decision he will have before him a raft of runway alternatives, not simply the one which has been put up to him already?

My final point is this: I have invited Minister Anderson to visit my electorate to inspect the impact of this runway on the community which would be affected by it. To date—and we only have 10 days to go—the minister has been unable to respond to my invitation. This would not be a political visit; it would simply be to show him how this runway proposal would affect my community. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: United Nations International Year of Older Persons

talk.start.para: —In this the United Nations declared International Year of Older Persons we pay tribute to the contributions of older Australians. I am proud to say that my electorate has embraced this special year with zeal. The Gold Coast International Year of Older Persons Committee has developed a jam-packed, all year program of events. To kick-start this program, on 16 January I was delighted that Bronwyn Bishop, the Minister for Aged Care, accepted my invitation to launch the Gold Coast activities for this special year, designed to acknowledge the value of older persons in our society. More than 120 special guests were delighted to share their ideas and to hear the minister speak with sincerity about the opportunities for older persons to contribute to the host of activities planned throughout this special year.

speech.para: The Gold Coast planning committee for the International Year of Older Persons wants to raise the awareness of the value of older people to society and their communities, acknowledging their skills, addressing issues concerning older people and, best of all, celebrating their worth. Like me, they want to see the problems of loneliness tackled seriously. They want to know that they are appreciated and recognised in society, and that they are safe in their homes.

The Gold Coast has long been a haven for retirees, many attracted to the coastal strip and to the city's hinterland suburbs because of the area's relaxed lifestyle and warm climate. One in every five people in my electorate is aged over 65. It is encouraging to see such a strong, united effort by so many members of our community to acknowledge and embrace the International Year of Older Persons.

On Australia Day the committee set up an `awareness stand' during the Gold Coast City Council's activities celebrating our national day. A retirement and lifestyle seminar is run monthly through Robina Centrelink and the 60s and Better Program. The 60s and Better coordinator, Anita Brennan, and her band of workers plan not to miss an opportunity to promote older persons in our community.

Recently I attended the first Mates for Plates morning, another initiative providing an opportunity for older persons to meet weekly and network with each other. Other activities planned throughout the year include a Life Options festival and a Wake Up and Walk celebration. The Southern Gold Coast 60s and Better Program and the Older Women's Network have banded together to hold an Art of Seniors exhibition for people 60 years and over. This exhibition will embrace paintings using any medium, and 10 per cent from the sale of all paintings will go to the Queensland Cancer Fund appeal. It is the aim of the group to raise the community's awareness of the creative skills and diversity of the older person.

I want to draw attention to another innovative project which extends across the nation, the Garden of Life schools project. The project encourages school children, particularly at primary level, to invite their grandparents to a special Internet day. The children record the reflections of their grandparents' gardens on the Garden of Life web site. All schools can take part by registering on the site, which will be promoted on 1 March nationally to create an awareness of the project. This project is an example of one way in which the barriers of age are broken down and different generations recognise and act upon their common interests.

I believe that as we stand on the verge of a new millennium the theme for this year is apt: Towards a society for all ages. I remind the House of the words of Kofi Annan, Secretary-General of the United Nations, in his address to launch the International Year of Older Persons. Mr Annan said that a society for all ages is one that does not caricature older persons as patients and pensioners, but instead sees them as both agents and beneficiaries of development.

The International Year of Older Persons gives people of all ages a chance to recognise the vital role of older persons in our society. I encourage all Australians to get involved in the programs held in their community and to join with others such as schools, businesses, community groups, local government and policy makers in planning events for their area.

I urge children and adults to speak with our elderly members about ageing and about the issues which affect us as we grow older. To the elderly: I challenge you to share your experiences and your positive life lessons, to offer your wisdom and to make an impact on a young person's life. It is by learning from those people who are willing to share their knowledge that we can grow as individuals and our society can prosper. One of my constituents reminded me of a beautiful quote by Oscar Wilde: `I am not young enough to know everything.' (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Last year I brought to the attention of the House the problems which residents living in the Shortland electorate, the electorate I represent, were having with Telstra. I detailed some of the problems residents were experiencing having new telephone lines connected since the government partially privatised Telstra. I also spent time detailing the experience of a young woman who had waited three days to have her phone service restored. Unfortunately, I had insufficient time to detail the problems some residents of Belmont were having with Telstra.

speech.para: Residents in that area have recently bought newly constructed units and have waited between two and three months for a telephone service to be connected. They finally contacted my office because they were desperately in need of a telephone. Telstra kept telling them that no lines were available. You could hardly say that was good business practice.

As we all know, Telstra enjoys a very special position in the market and, now it is partially privatised, it is exploiting that position and putting profit before service. Instead of ensuring that all Telstra users have good service, or in some cases a service, Telstra is now more concerned with profit than service. This was clearly demonstrated to me during the recent election campaign. A person who lived in Gwandalan, which is part of the Shortland electorate, contacted me. She had been waiting for three days to have her phone connected, and so had a large part of Gwandalan.

The majority of Gwandalan was without a telephone. Only a couple of hundred homes had a telephone. All the shops had been without a telephone service. The Gwandalan Bowling Club, the post office, the lottery agent and the general store in Gwandalan had no access whatsoever to electronic services. All the homes and residents were also without service. There are a number of elderly people who live in that area and they felt they were definitely being put at risk because if they needed to contact an ambulance or such they had no telephone access. This was an enormous problem for the businesses in the area because they had to provide services through the electronic banking system and they needed computer access to be able to do this. The problems were purportedly caused by the keel of a yacht breaking the underwater telecommunication cable across Lake Macquarie. I found it most interesting that Telstra were unable to find the break in the cable yet attributed the problem to a yacht breaking it. Telstra spent three days looking for it. In the end they gave up looking for the break and just laid a new cable.

There are two things I would like to put. Firstly, I do not think the problem would have been solved if I had not brought it to the attention of the media. Telstra were very slow to respond to the needs of the people of that area. It was only when the media got hold of it that they actually did something to help the people of Gwandalan. Secondly, now Telstra are refusing to pay compensation to those businesses that were affected by this breakage.

One person, Mr Greg Campbell, the owner of the store that has the lottery agency, lost $9,240. Telstra said: `We regret that we have caused inconvenience to you in this matter', but felt that the matter was dealt with quite effectively. They said that the incident occurred on 20 September and on 25 September the service was restored, and they put the problem down to the breaking of the cable by the yacht. But no evidence whatsoever was found that the cable was broken. No evidence was reported of a yacht. No yacht was identified as saying that the cable was broken.

I do not think the way Telstra has responded to the problems of Mr Campbell and all the other residents in that area is good enough. It was not until the media became involved that Telstra supplied the residents and businesses with mobile phones. This is what we can expect in the future if there is full privatisation of Telstra. I urge members of the government to reject that. Do not go ahead with the full privatisation of Telstra. I know that you have the same problems with privatisation that I have.

talk.start.para: —I rise to pay tribute to three extraordinary women from my electorate in Parramatta. These are women who make a selfless contribution to the local community but who would not necessarily expect to receive the sort of acknowledgment they deserve and would certainly never seek the limelight or praise.

speech.para: The first of those is Mrs Betty Holland, who has been the President of the Wentworthville Pensioners Welfare Association for the last nine years. Her husband, Ted, has been the Treasurer of that association for the last five years. The two of them together look after the pensioners of Wentworthville with the most extraordinary dedication and pastoral care.

I have had numerous occasions to address the throng who meet to play bingo and carpet bowls and to generally catch up with each other. There is a marvellous atmosphere there, largely created by Betty. All political persuasions are represented, and I often have my fiercest partisan debates and disputes with the members of the association who are not of my political persuasion, but it is always conducted in good spirit and good faith. Betty's husband, Ted, is very ill at the moment and has just come home from hospital. He has been diagnosed with cancer. There are still elements of optimism about his prognosis and we do wish Ted all the best. Betty and Ted are making and have made an extraordinary contribution to their peers in Wentworthville, and I just want to acknowledge that today.

The second woman is Envoy Esselina van Leusden, who is a soldier in the Salvation Army and who I first met on Pendle Hill Station at 6.30 a.m. one day in the midst of the last election campaign. I came to know Envoy van Leusden because she appears every morning, five mornings a week, from 6 a.m. to 8 a.m. at Toongabbie, Wentworthville and Pendle Hill stations. She has been doing that five days a week, 52 weeks a year, for the last 15 years.

She is constantly cheerful and never flustered. She simply sits quietly with her little box. The thing I noticed was the pleasure on the faces of the men and women, the daily commuters, who get on the train and especially have a few coins in their pockets to put in Envoy van Leusden's box. She receives from them by name. She asks them how their family is going. She is a permanent feature of their lives and is just a bright spark of cheerfulness at the start of the day for literally thousands of commuters in my electorate. I think she is the sort of person who makes our community worth living in. She is making an unbelievable sacrifice. One day I asked her why she did it and she said, `I do it because it gives me great pleasure. I wouldn't do anything other than serve the Lord in my small way.' So I want to salute Envoy van Leusden.

The final local hero of Parramatta is Mrs Betty Schofield OAM, who was the somewhat stern and certainly commanding matron of Parramatta Hospital for 15 years. Betty Schofield is a woman not to be taken lightly. She is a formidable presence. When she indicates to the local federal member that she will be paying him a visit, my whole staff goes into tremors of trepidation. She usually comes to see me about some matter of maladministration to do with the quality of patient care. She brings to bear on those representations her lifetime of public service as a very senior nurse and matron of one of the oldest and, up until it was replaced by Westmead Hospital, busiest hospitals in Sydney.

Betty Schofield commanded and rallied the nursing troops on the occasion of the Granville train disaster, in which over 100 Australian commuters lost their lives in the worst train disaster in our history. It was Betty who oversaw the nursing response to that terrible tragedy and crisis. She still serves on the Arts Advisory Committee of Parramatta City Council. She is getting somewhat frail, but her mind is razor sharp. I think it is fitting that this parliament acknowledge the contribution of those three extraordinary and completely selfless women who make Parramatta the great pleasure it is for me to represent.

talk.start.para: —The debate having concluded, the Main Committee stands adjourned until a date and time to be announced by the Deputy Speaker.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 11 November 1998:

question.para: Is the Sydney Airports Corporation Limited seeking tenders for the provision of security services at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport; if so, will the Commonwealth Government's competitive neutrality principles apply to the tendering process and, if so, what are the implications of the principles.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Commonwealth has agreed to allow major airport operators some choice in the agency that can provide Counter Terrorist First Response (CTFR) services at their individual airports. This choice is limited to the Australian Federal Police (AFP), the Australian Protective Service (APS) and the relevant State/Territory police force. Consistent with this policy, Sydney Airports Corporation Limited (SACL) has sought expressions of interest from the AFP, the APS and the NSW Police for the provision of these services at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.
Treasury has advised that this process is subject to the Commonwealth's competitive neutrality principles and that all bids are required to comply with the principles.
Complaints concerning the application of the competitive neutrality principles can be made to the Commonwealth Competitive Complaints Office within the Productivity Commission.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 11 November 1998:

question.para: (1) For what social security entitlements are New Zealand citizens in Australia eligible under the terms of the International Social Security Agreement between Australia and New Zealand.
(2) Does the waiting period for social security entitlements for New Zealand citizens in Australia differ from that applying to citizens from other nations; if so, (a) how and (b) why.
(3) Are persons entering Australia from Pacific island nations covered by the International Social Security Agreement between Australia and New Zealand.
(4) Under the agreement, what are the entitlements of Australian citizens entering New Zealand.
(5) What is the basis of the entitlements referred to in part (4) and how do they differ from those of New Zealand citizens entering Australia.
(6) Does the basis of the entitlements of Australian citizens entering New Zealand differ from citizens of other nations.

(7) For each category of social security entitlement for persons entering Australia and covered by the agreement, (a) how many recipients are there (i) in total and (ii) from each nation if the entitlement extends to Pacific island nations beyond New Zealand and (b) what was the cost to Australia in 1996-97.
(8) Is the Minister able to say how the costs to Australia referred to in part (7) compare with the corresponding costs in 1996-97 to New Zealand (a) in total and (b) for each comparable entitlement.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) NZ citizens who have been NZ residents for at least 10 years can use this NZ residence to meet minimum residence requirements for the following Australian benefits:
. Age Pension;
. Disability Support Pension;
. Parenting Payment—only sole parents (subject to a 6 month waiting period if they are not widowed)—and women whose partners receive age or disability support pensions.
Australian Wife and Widow B Pensions are also covered under the agreement but these pensions can no longer be granted.
(Note that the agreement is based on residence and not only NZ citizens are covered.)
(2) (a) For the following Australian payments, NZ citizens must serve the same waiting period as other new arrivals (104 weeks):
. Special Benefit;
. Carer Payment;
. Widow Allowance;
. Youth Allowance;
. Austudy Payment.
There is a 104 week waiting period for the following entitlements, but NZ citizens do not serve it:
. Partner Allowance;
. Mature Age Allowance;
. Sickness Allowance;
. Mobility Allowance;
. Seniors Health Card.
There is a 104 week waiting period for Newstart Allowance but, under the terms of the social security agreement, NZ citizens currently only serve a 6 month waiting period.

(2) (b) The 104 week waiting period for Partner, Mature Age, Sickness and Mobility Allowances and the Seniors Health Card applies only to new arrivals who have been issued with permanent visas. New Zealand citizens entering Australia are special category visa holders.

(3) People from Pacific island nations (or from any other country) are covered by the social security agreement between Australia and New Zealand for early access to Age and Disability Support Pensions and Parenting Payment if they have had 10 years residence in NZ. The definition of residence in NZ does not include residence in the Cook Islands, Niue, Tokelau or any other Pacific nation.

People from the Cook Islands, Niue and Tokelau are New Zealand citizens and are covered by the Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement when entering Australia. They are subject to the agreement's 6 month waiting period for Newstart Allowance and Parenting Payment for sole parents.
(4) Australian citizens who have been Australian residents for at least 10 years can use this Australian residence to meet minimum residence requirements for the following New Zealand benefits:
. NZ Superannuation;
. Veteran's Pension
. Invalid's Benefit;
. Widow's Benefit;
. Domestic Purposes Benefit for Sole Parents (subject to a 26 week waiting period if they are relying on their Australian citizenship or former Australian residence for the right to remain in NZ).
Under the agreement, Australian citizens can claim NZ unemployment benefits after serving a 6 month waiting period instead of the 2 year waiting period applying to citizens of other countries.

(5) NZ Superannuation is paid to those who have reached 63 years of age (rising to 65 by 2001). Australian Age Pension is paid to men at age 65 and women at age 61 (rising to 65 by 2013). NZ Superannuation is not subject to income or assets tests but all payments are taxable and there is no "tax free area". New Zealand Superannuation is subject to a dollar for dollar reduction of any foreign pension. Australian Age Pension is subject to a dollar for dollar reduction of foreign pensions only when the Australian pension is paid under an international agreement. NZ Superannuation can be paid at the married rate when only one of a couple qualifies for the payment. Australian Age pension cannot be paid at the married rate in such cases. NZ Superannuation maximum rates are $422.001 a fortnight for a single person and $316.30 a fortnight for each member of a couple. Australian Age Pension maximum rates are $357.30 a fortnight for a single person and $298.10 a fortnight for each member of a couple.

NZ Veteran's Pension is for ex-service personnel of 63 years of age or more and who qualify for a war disablement pension of at least 70% or more (or who are not yet 63 and unable to work for a long time). This is an alternative to NZ Superannuation, like Australian Service Pension is an alternative to Age Pension.

NZ Invalid's Benefit is equivalent to Australian Disability Support Pension. For the former, a claimant must be totally blind or both permanently and severely restricted in the capacity to work. For the latter, a claimant must be permanently blind or have a physical, intellectual or psychiatric impairment of 20% or more under the impairment tables and a continuing inability to work. NZ Invalid's Benefit can be paid at a married rate when only one of a member of a couple qualifies. Australian Disability Support Pension cannot be paid at the married rate in such cases. The basic single rate of NZ Invalid's Benefit is $304.46 a fortnight for a single person and $253.71 a fortnight for each member of a couple. Australian rates are $357.30 a fortnight and $298.10 respectively.

NZ Widow's Benefit is for women over 18 whose husbands have died (there are also a number of more specific eligibility requirements). It is no longer possible to be granted a direct Australian equivalent under the agreement.

NZ Domestic Purposes Benefit for sole parents is available only to those who are or have been legally married or have attained the age of 18 years. There is no minimum age for Australian Parenting Payment for sole parents but a claimant under the agreement with NZ must have reached the minimum age required by NZ. A recipient of Domestic Purposes Benefit for sole parents must have a dependent child under 18. A sole parent receiving Australian Parenting Payment must have a dependent child under 16 or a child who attracts Child Disability Allowance. NZ beneficiaries with a child aged 7-13 are required to attend an interview once a year. Those with a child aged 14 or over must seek part-time work. Australian Parenting Payment is not activity tested. The basic rate of Domestic Purposes Benefit for a sole parent with one dependent child is $348.88 a fortnight. The Australian equivalent rate is $357.30 a fortnight plus a maximum of $96.40 a fortnight family allowance and $36.70 guardian allowance (total $490.40).

NZ unemployment benefits have a 24 month waiting period for new arrivals, but Australian citizens entering NZ only wait 6 months. Similarly, Australian Newstart Allowance has a 104 week waiting period for new arrivals, but NZ citizens entering Australia only wait 6 months. In NZ, if the partner of an unemployed person is not granted a benefit, the unemployed person may (subject to certain conditions) get the married rate of payment. This is not possible for recipients of the equivalent Australian benefit.
(6) Yes.

Under the social security agreement with Australia, early access to specified payments is possible, for people (including Australian citizens) who have specified periods of Australian residence. The waiting period for NZ unemployment payments is reduced from 2 years to 6 months for Australian citizens and former Australian residents.

(7) The cost of paying base pensions to NZ Agreement pensioners in 1996-97 was approximately $52 million. The total cost of paying social security entitlements (including base pension plus auxiliary payments eg. Rent Assistance, Family Allowance) to all NZ Agreement pensioners in 1996-97 was approximately $62 million. These costs were offset by $26,084,695 in reimbursement from New Zealand. This is only part of the total New Zealand reimbursement figure for 1996-97 as explained below.

The Social Security Agreement with New Zealand also requires New Zealand to reimburse Australia for selected pensioners whose entitlement does not depend on the Agreement, but arises under domestic law. The total amount of reimbursement received from New Zealand in 1996-97 for all reimbursable pensioners was $46,329,427.
Age Pension:
At June 1997, Age Pension was paid under the New Zealand Agreement to people with the following countries of birth recorded:
The cost of paying pensions to NZ Agreement Age Pensioners in 1996-97 was approximately $39.4 million.

The total cost of social security entitlements for NZ Agreement Age Pensioners in 1996-97 was approximately $42.5 million. These costs were offset by $21.8 million in reimbursement for Age Pensioners from New Zealand.
Disability Support Pension:
At June 1997, Disability Support Pension was paid under the New Zealand Agreement to people with the following countries of birth recorded:
The cost of paying pensions to New Zealand Agreement Disability Support Pensioners in 1996-97 was approximately $5.5 million.

The total cost of social security entitlements for NZ Agreement Disability Support Pensioners in 1996-97 was approximately $6.4 million. This cost was offset by $2.5 million in reimbursement for Disability Support Pensioners from New Zealand.
Wife Pension:
At June 1997, Wife Pension was paid under the New Zealand Agreement to people with the following countries of birth recorded:
The cost of paying pensions to New Zealand Agreement Wife Pensioners in 1996-97 was approximately $1.9 million.

The total cost of paying social security entitlements to NZ Agreement Wife Pensioners in 1996-97 was approximately $2.2 million. This was offset by $0.8 million in reimbursement for Wife Pensioners from New Zealand.
Widow B Pension:
At June 1997, Widow B Pension was paid under the New Zealand Agreement to people with the following countries of birth recorded:
The cost of paying pensions to New Zealand Agreement Widow B Pensioners in 1996-97 was approximately $722,000.

The total cost of paying social security entitlements to NZ Agreement Widow B Pensioners in 1996-97 was approximately $0.8 million. This cost was offset by $0.4 million in reimbursement for Widow B Pensioners from New Zealand.
Sole Parent Pension:
At June 1997, Sole Parent Pension (now called Parenting Payment) was paid under the New Zealand Agreement to people with the following countries of birth recorded:
The cost of paying pensions to New Zealand Agreement Sole Parent Pensioners in 1996-97 was approximately $4.4 million.

The total cost of paying social security entitlements to NZ Agreement Sole Parent Pensioners in 1996-97 was approximately $10.3 million. This cost was offset by $0.6 million in reimbursement for Sole Parent Pensioners from New Zealand.
(8) The New Zealand Department of Social Welfare is unable to provide figures which are exactly comparable to those provided for Australia in part (7) of this question.

The New Zealand Department of Social Welfare keeps records of amounts paid to pensioners who are reimbursable by Australia. Most, but not all, of these are Agreement pensioners. In 1996-97, New Zealand paid a total $NZ1.6 million to 189 reimbursable pensioners. (This amount does not include supplementary payments such as accommodation supplement, disability allowance or special benefits.) In 1996-97, New Zealand received $NZ791,284 in reimbursement from Australia.

The above amount breaks down into the following specific entitlements. New Zealand paid $NZ1,500,644 in New Zealand Superannuation to 171 reimbursable superannuitants, and received $NZ717,015 in reimbursement from Australia. Veterans Pension is not shown separately to New Zealand Superannuation. $NZ86,602 was paid to 13 reimbursable Invalid's Beneficiaries and $NZ62,487 was received in reimbursement from Australia. $NZ3,308 was paid to one reimbursable Widow's Beneficiary and $NZ2,227 was received in reimbursement from Australia. $NZ18,750 was paid to four reimbursable Domestic Purposes Beneficiaries and $NZ9,555 was received in reimbursement from Australia.
Note: 1 All NZ fortnightly payments are quoted in Australia dollars, converted from NZ dollars using the on demand airmail buying rate for cheques as at 26 November 1998.

subdebateinfo.title: Employment National and Job Network: Offices
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 13)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment Services, upon notice, on 11 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Will he provide a list showing for each (a) office or (b) outreach office established after 1 May 1998 by (i) Employment National and (ii) a Job Network member the (A) exact address, (B) telephone number, (C) federal electoral division in which it is located, (D) name of the manager and (E) days and hours of opening.
(2) Will he provide a list showing which (a) office or (b) outreach office originally established by (i) Employment National and (ii) a Job Network member was not fully operating at 3 October 1998.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) See my answer to Parliamentary Question on Notice Number 15.

The Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business is able to provide a list of current Job Network sites for items (A), (B) and (C). This list as at 11 January 1999 runs to more than 30 pages and has been provided to the honourable member separately on a disk.

However, as the days and hours of opening vary to suit local conditions and may vary seasonally, it is not possible to provide such detail.

Taringa, Toowoomba, Warwick, Dalby, Roma, Mackay, Gladstone, Rockhampton, Emerald
Esperance, Northam, Geraldton, Kalgoorlie, Carnarvon, Broome.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 11 November 1998:

question.para: (1) What measures has the Minister's Department undertaken which are categorised as positive discrimination programs, that is, providing preference to certain citizens on the basis of their gender, sexuality, age, race, place of birth or some other personal characteristic.
(2) What are the details and funding commitments involved in each case.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) and (2). The Treasury portfolio does not operate programs categorised as positive discrimination programs in the sense conveyed in the question. However, there are some programs of limited size in the consumer affairs area that target particular groups in the community.

The Government set aside an additional $1 million in the 1998-99 Budget to support national consumer information initiatives to be drawn down over the next three years. This is in answer to recent Government research which reveals that many consumers such as those living in rural and remote areas, people on low incomes, those with limited English and older Australians have trouble accessing useful consumer information in our fast changing marketplace.

Under the Commonwealth Financial Counselling Program approximately $2 million has been allocated in 1998/99 to 45 agencies throughout Australia to provide free financial counselling to consumers in low income households experiencing serious financial difficulties.

One service under the Program primarily targets the Aboriginal community at Alice Springs. The service is provided under the auspices of the Tangentyere Council and 95% of its clients are Aboriginal people. An amount of $48,858 has been provided in 1998/99.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Aged Care, upon notice, on 11 November 1998:

question.para: (1) What measures has the Minister's Department undertaken which are categorised as positive discrimination programs, that is, providing preference to certain citizens on the basis of their gender, sexuality, age, race, place of birth or some other personal characteristic.
(2) What are the details and funding commitments involved in each case.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) My Department is committed to ensuring the equitable delivery of high quality health and aged care and in doing so, takes account of the need to make services available which are appropriate to the particular needs and culture of people using the services.
The Government has focused its priorities on those most in need within Australian society.
(2) Full details of appropriations for specific programs are included in the Portfolio Budget Statements for the Department.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 11 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Does he support the construction of Sydney's second international airport at Badgerys Creek on the outskirts of Sydney's western suburbs; if so, why; if not, why not.

(2) Has the Government's environmental impact study (EIS) on constructing Sydney's second international airport at Badgerys Creek been conducted in a manner which is (a) transparent, (b) comprehensive and (c) above reproach; if so, why.
(3) Will constructing Sydney's second international airport at Badgerys Creek add value to (a) Sydney's, (b) NSW's and (c) Australia's (i) transport and (ii) tourism infrastructure; if so, why.

(4) Did the NSW Environment Protection Agency (NSW EPA) find that (a) Badgerys Creek will have a disproportionate impact on photochemical smog in the area and would be a major source of the air pollutant nitrogen dioxide, (b) Badgerys Creek will generate noise that would expose many persons to levels which would exceed Australian standards, and (c) the draft EIS summary on Badgerys Creek did not demonstrate the real impacts on the community for any particular site option; if so, what is his response to the finding.

(5) Did Mr Neil Shepherd, the Director-General of the NSW EPA, state that there are serious deficiencies in the Commonwealth's approach to conducting an EIS on Badgerys Creek and that the EPA is concerned about the implications of this development for air quality in the Sydney basin; if so, what is his response to the statements.

(6) Have the NSW Government and Opposition both withdrawn their support from the construction of Sydney's second international airport at Badgerys Creek; if so, how will the airport be constructed without the support of the NSW Government.

(7) Did the independent auditor of the Badgerys Creek EIS find that the EIS was (a) deficient, (b) limited, and (c) ambiguous and that as a result of time and cost constraints imposed by the Department of Transport and Regional Development, it generally does not go into the degree of detail that could reasonably be expected for such a major proposal; if so, what is his response to the findings.

(8) Did the independent auditor of the Badgerys Creek EIS find that the EIS had failed to (a) examine the environmental effect of not building a new airport, (b) provide an adequate economic analysis of the development, (c) build community confidence in the EIS, (d) identify how Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and a new airport at Badgerys Creek would operate together and (e) satisfactorily examine the impact that noise generated by the airport would have on Sydney's population, especially those living in Sydney's west; if so, what is his response.

(9) Will he reopen the process of evaluating proposals for building the Sydney-Canberra Very Fast Train (VFT) to ensure that the Transrapid proposal is given further consideration alongside that of the Speedrail consortium; if not, why not.
(10) Will he conduct an EIS into building Sydney's second international airport outside the Sydney basin and being served by the Sydney-Canberra VFT; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Government is committed to conducting a thorough and transparent Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) process on the proposed second airport site at Badgerys Creek.

A second airport will be required to handle the growing demand for air travel and to manage the level of aircraft noise experienced by Sydney residents. Additional airport facilities are essential to Sydney's continuing role as a major commercial and employment centre. The major users of Sydney Airport have endorsed the need for additional airport infrastructure in the Sydney basin, and have acknowledged that a second airport is needed.
(2) The Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) process is being undertaken in accordance with the requirements of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974.

These requirements have been supplemented, for the first time, by the appointment of an independent auditor to scrutinise the entire EIS process. This clearly demonstrates the Government's commitment to a transparent and rigorous environmental assessment process.
(3) A second airport will be required to handle the growing demand for air travel to Sydney, NSW and Australia. This will have flow on benefits for the tourism industry.
A major airport at Badgerys Creek would be one of the biggest employers in western Sydney and would bring with it major infrastructure improvements in road and rail networks.
(4) The NSW Government submission on the draft EIS, which incorporates comments from the NSW EPA, has raised a number of issues related to information contained in the draft EIS.
A response to the issues raised by the NSW Government will be contained in the Final EIS that is currently being prepared.
(5) See answer to (4).
(6) This question is a matter for the NSW Government and opposition. No decisions will be made about the second airport until the EIS process has been completed.
(7) The independent auditor has raised a number of issues related to information contained in the draft EIS.
A response to the issues raised by the independent auditor will be contained in the Final EIS that is currently being prepared.
(8) See the answer to (7).

The Prime Minister's announcement of 4 August 1998 that the Commonwealth, NSW and ACT Governments had accepted the VHST Project Control Group's recommendation to proceed with a Proving-Up Stage with Speedrail followed a very detailed examination by the three Governments. In 1997 the three Governments established a Project Control Group (PCG) to assess the proposals and to make recommendations to the Governments. The four proponents that proceeded to the final stage of the VHST process all submitted detailed proposals. These proposals were then each assessed against a comprehensive set of criteria, as is standard practice for infrastructure projects.

The PCG established a committee called the Project Evaluation Committee (the PEC) to examine the proposals in detail. The PEC consisted of representatives of the three Governments as well as technical and financial experts. It also drew on work done by a number of other experts, in such areas as economics, patronage estimations, rail operations and design, and the environment. The PEC scored the proposals according to their compliance with the terms of the project brief and also examined the economic viability and the net cost to Government of the proposals closely. The PEC found that the Speedrail proposal complied best with the project brief. The PCG's recommendation that the three Governments consider agreeing to a proving up stage with Speedrail drew on this work.
(10) No decisions will be made about the airport until the current EIS on the Badgerys Creek proposal has been completed and considered by Government.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 11 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Is it important after events of international significance regarding human rights for him or a representative of the Australian diplomatic corps to state the Commonwealth's view of the event; if not why not.

(2) Following the arrest of the former dictator of Chile, General Augusto Pinochet, in London on 17 October 1998, has (a) he, (b) the Australian High Commissioner to the UK or (c) a member of his Department expressed the Government's support to the British Government for the action it had taken; if not, why not.

(3) Has (a) he, (b) the Australian Ambassador to Spain or (c) a member of his Department expressed the Government's support to the Spanish Government for the steps it is taking to bring General Pinochet to trial on charges of mass murder; if not, why not.

(4) Has (a) he, (b) the Australian Ambassador to Chile or (c) a member of his Department expressed the Government's support of the steps the British and Spanish Governments have taken to bring General Pinochet to trial on charges of mass murder to the Chilean Government; if not, why not.

(5) What is the Government's position on the arrest of General Pinochet and the attempt by the Spanish Government to extradite him to Spain to stand trial for the mass murder of Spanish citizens during his rule.

(6) Does the Government support in principle a judicial inquiry by either the Spanish or Chilean Governments into General Pinochet's role in the disappearances and deaths of over 3000 persons in Chile between 1973 and 1990.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows

answer.para: (1) The Australian Government regularly makes known its position regarding human rights, including its views on events of international significance. A recent example is the Parliamentary motion moved by the Prime Minister and passed by the House of Representatives on 10 December 1998 to mark the 50th Anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (UDHR), which reaffirmed Australia's enduring commitment to the principles enshrined in the UDHR.

(2) (3) and (4) Following the arrest of Senator Pinochet, neither the Australian government nor its diplomatic representatives have made representations to the governments of Spain, the United Kingdom or Chile. The Australian Government believes that it would be inappropriate to comment on a matter that is being considered by the British legal system.

(5) The Australian Government recognises that there were many serious human rights abuses in Chile during Senator Pinochet's Presidency. The Government is committed to the protection and promotion of human rights as an integral part of its foreign policy. However, the Australian Government accepts that the issue of whether Senator Pinochet should be extradited to Spain is for the relevant British authorities to decide. Senator Pinochet's rights and obligations will be determined in accordance with existing arrangements under British and Spanish law.

(6) The Australian Government is committed to the promotion and protection of human rights and welcomes efforts by other governments to advance these goals. The Australian Government recognises the right of the Spanish or any other government to seek extradition of persons alleged to have committed human rights abuses. The Australian Government also recognises the sovereign right of the Chilean people and Government to determine the most appropriate means of delivering and consoli dating a transition to full democracy. The Australian Government does not believe that it would be appropriate or helpful to comment on the means chosen by Chile to attain this goal.

subdebateinfo.title: Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service: Far North Queensland
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 76)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veteran's Affairs, upon notice, on 12 November 1998:

question.para: (1) How many Vietnam veterans live in the Far North Queensland region.

(2) Is there an outposted office of the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service at Smithfield in Cairns; if so, (a) when was it established and (b) has a full-time staff position at the office become vacant; if so, (i) when and (ii) has the Government decided not to fill the position; if so, why.
(3) What is the location of the nearest office of the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service to residents of Cairns.
(4) If there is an office at Smithfield, (a) who owns the premises, (b) what annual rent is paid and (c) what is the duration of the lease.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Veterans' Affairs; Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Based on the Vietnam Veterans Mortality Study there are 714 veterans living in the area bounded by Tully, Mt Isa and Thursday Island.

(2) No. The Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service has never established an outposted counselling centre in Cairns. Rather, the service leased premises at 11 Stanton Place, Smithfield as a base for the operations of an officer employed as a member of the Townsville staff. This officer was engaged to coordinate the services provided by contract counsellors for Far North Queensland, including but not exclusively those in the Cairns region. With the resignation of this officer, and the appointment of a Townsville-based incumbent, the premises are no longer required.

(3) The nearest Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service office to the residents of Cairns is Townsville. However, 12 contract counsellors service the region directly with 113 referrals being made to them in the past 9 months.

(4) (a) The owners of the Stanton Street premises are Bruno and Serafino Data. (b) The annual rent was $11,644 for year 1, $12,125 for year 2, and $12,610 for year 3. (c) The lease was for 3 years. As the premises are no longer required, DVA Corporate Services attempted to negotiate a payout of the lease. This was rejected by the owners. Although the premises have cost $12,610 for the current year the relocation of the Country Outreach Coordinator position to Townsville has resulted in additional savings to the Department of $30,500 through the transfer of office equipment and fittings, and the relinquishment of the Commonwealth car.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Defence Force: Special Event Participation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 80)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 November 1998:

question.para: Did the ADF assist or take part in the staging of the 1998 Australian Football League (AFL) grand final; if so, (a) what form did the assistance or participation take, (b) what was the cost of each component of assistance or participation, (c) was the AFL asked to pay and (d) did the ADF or his Department receive any benefits from the AFL.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Australian Defence Force (ADF) did provide assistance to the 1998 Australian Football League (AFL) grand final. It was included as part of the Public Events of Significance program, which is a series of selected events in which the ADF wishes to be involved because it provides a substantial public relations, recruiting and/or training opportunity for Defence.
(a) and (b) Assistance provided and associated direct costs to the ADF were:
Roulettes aerobatic display team—$9,180;
F/A 18 display—$20,856;
Army Band for Grand Final Parade (Fri 25 Sep)—$3,885;
Fanfare trumpeters (tri-service) in full dress uniform (22 personnel)—$8,843;
Tri-service Band for National Anthem presentation (24 personnel)—$3,959.
Total direct cost was $46,723, $20,000 of which was a salary component.

It is estimated that approximately 120 military personnel responded to a request from the AFL for volunteers to help with general support for the staging of the Grand Final. These personnel were volunteers acting in a private capacity, they were not on duty and were not in uniform. As volunteers, they were provided with lunch by the AFL and with seating to watch the match.
(c) The AFL was not asked to pay the cost of the support provided.

(d) No benefits were received from the AFL by ADF personnel or by Defence generally as a direct result of the support provided. Defence expected to derive Public Relations and Recruiting value from performing in front of the large audience in attendance and from the National television coverage.

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport: Incidents and Accidents
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 143)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Do the majority of aircraft accidents occur within a 10 kilometre radius of the point of take-off if so, what does the statistic reveal.

(2) Have the probabilities of an aircraft accident occurring at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport been researched; if so (a) what does the research reveal and (b) what are the probabilities of an accident occurring during (i) take-off and (ii) landing.
(3) How many aircraft accidents have occurred at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport in the last 40 years.
(4) What advice has his Department received on the probabilities of an aircraft accident occurring at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) airport during the next 40 years.
(5) If his Department maintains that it has not received any specific advice on these matters would he provide his reply on the basis of the information of which his department is aware.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Data derived from the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) electronic Occurrence Analysis and Safety Information System (OASIS) indi cates that between 1 January 1987 to 31 December 1996 there were 1,964 reported fixed wing aircraft accidents in Australia. During this period, 1,557 (79%) accidents occurred within 8 kilometres (the closest appropriate database search parameter) of an aerodrome.

In addition to the BASI statistics, The Boeing Commercial Airplane Group conducted a survey of Hull Loss Accidents involving the worldwide commercial jet fleet between 1959—1994. The results of the survey revealed that 24.8% of accidents occurred during take-off and initial climb and 43.4% occurred during final approach and landing.

(2) The risk of an aircraft accident at Sydney Airport was researched as part of the Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) for the third runway. The EIS stated that take-offs and landings are the most hazardous phases of flight, however, no separate calculations were made of the probabilities of accidents occurring during take-off and landing (p 25-13, Supplement to the draft EIS).

(3) The BASI OASIS system indicates that during the period 1 January 1969 to 8 January 1999 there were twenty-seven reported accidents at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. Of these, 16 involved aircraft engaged in commercial passenger operations.

(4) No specific studies have been made into the probabilities of an accident occurring at Sydney Airport during the next 40 years. Given the rapid rate of technological change it is not considered feasible that meaningful projections could be made over a 40 year time horizon.
(5) See above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation has advised that it has no record of an occurrence at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport involving an Ansett aircraft on 21 March 1998.
Ansett Airlines has also advised that it has no record of an occurrence at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport on 21 March 1998.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: Further to the answer to question No. 99 (Hansard , 20 August 1996, page 3289), would he bring up-to-date the information which was provided on the number of (a) air safety incidents at or over Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and (b) occasions that the 11 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew has been breached since 3 May 1996.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) Air safety incidents at or over Sydney (Kingsford- Smith) airport since the east-west runway was re-opened [update from information provided to 3 May 1996].
Since 3 May 1996, BASI has received 718 safety incident reports involving air traffic at or over Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport.
- 538 of these were assessed as Category 5 occurrences.

Category 5 occurrences are those which are primarily of statistical interest and are recorded on the BASI database for future trend analysis. The information as reported to the Bureau is available to the public on request.
- 178 were assessed as Category 4 occurrences.

Category 4 occurrences are those where the facts either; do not indicate a serious safety deficiency but the circumstances are sufficiently complex to require detailed information from the pilot, operator and/or other interested parties; or, some investigation is needed to expand and/or substantiate the initial information. Reports are available to the public on request.
- 2 were assessed as Category 3 occurrences.

Category 3 occurrences are those where the initial indications suggest potentially serious safety deficiencies. Consequently, an in-depth investigation is required to satisfy the concern for public safety. The report will include a Safety Action Statement detailing the relevant safety actions. Reports are available to the public on request.
The first Category 3 incident occurred on 15 October 1997.

A Boeing 747 aircraft (B747) arrived at Sydney 35 minutes prior to the end of the curfew. The aircraft was being operated in accordance with a concession which permitted arrival prior to the end of the curfew, subject to certain conditions. One of these conditions was that the aircraft should use only runway 34L for arrival.

Enroute to Sydney and after passing the point at which the aircraft could divert to an alternate aerodrome with sufficient fuel remaining, a change in the wind direction, different to that which was forecast, passed through the Sydney area. This wind change made conditions on runway 34L operationally unacceptable to the crew of the aircraft. The crew elected to continue to Sydney and notified air traffic services that they had a requirement to land prior to the end of the curfew as the aircraft had insufficient fuel to divert to an alternate aerodrome. The aircraft subsequently landed on runway 16R.
The second Category 3 incident occurred on 22 July 1998

A Fairchild Industries Inc SA227-AC (Metro) aircraft landed on runway 34R, with an instruction to exit on taxiway Tango 1 and taxi via taxiway Juliet (for identification purposes, taxiways are named in accordance with the international phonetic alphabet). When approaching a mandatory holding point on taxiway Juliet, the pilot contacted the surface movement controller (SMC) and was instructed to taxi via taxiway Bravo and hold short of runway 25. This instruction was read back correctly by the pilot.

Tower controllers subsequently observed the Metro taxiing along taxiway Juliet, past the entry to taxiway Bravo, towards runway 34L. At that time a Boeing 737 (B737) was touching down on runway 34L. The SMC instructed the pilot of the Metro to stop. As there was no reply the instruction was immediately repeated, and was subsequently acknowledged by the pilot. The Metro came to a stop at the edge of runway 34L. The pilot of the B737 was also instructed to stop immediately, but the aircraft was too close to the intersection of the runway with taxiway Juliet to comply. The pilot steered the B737 to the left of the runway centreline to increase its separation from the Metro, subsequently passing about 25 metres in front of that aircraft, at about 80 kts.

At the time of the occurrence the weather was fine, there were no works taking place in the vicinity of the runway/taxiway intersection, and all relevant taxiway lights, runway holding point lights and movement area guidance signs were reported to have been functioning normally.
The investigation is continuing. A copy of the final report can be sent to Mr McClelland if required.
(b) Occasions that the 11 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew have been breached since 3 May 1996.

On 8 February 1997 a Russian Presidential Ilyushin aircraft departed Sydney Airport at 23:34 without approval. In addition, since 3 May 1996 there have been three occasions when aircraft landed at Sydney Airport up to two minutes before the end of the 11pm to 6am curfew and one occasion when an aircraft landed two minutes after the start of the 11pm to 6am curfew. Summary details of these incidents have been included in reports provided to the Sydney Airport Community Forum.

subdebateinfo.title: Bureau of Air Safety Investigation Report
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 156)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: Further to the answer to question No. 2618 (Hansard , 28 May 1998, page 4224), what was (a) his Department's and (b) Airservices Australia's response to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation report published in January 1997 entitled `An analysis of incidents involving air crew failing to comply with air traffic clearances: June- August 1996.'

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: There were two recommendations arising from this report. Neither of the recommendations was directed specifically at the then Department of Transport and Regional Development:
The following recommendation, reference R970010, was issued to Airservices Australia on 31 January 1997 and stated:
The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation recommends that Airservices Australia:
1. Review the current methods of flow control management with the aim of minimising the need for vectoring aircraft within the STAR environment. (STAR—Standard Terminal Arrival Route).
2. Minimise the practice of instructing aircraft to resume a STAR once vectored off the STAR.
3. Ensure that SIDs and STARs, at all locations, are developed in accordance with consistent design principles. (SID—Standard Instrument Departure).
4. Maximise the use of ICAO standard radio phraseology in accordance with accepted worldwide practice.
5. Ensure that STAR design is compatible with aircraft FMS programs, especially for STARs which are not runway specific. (FMS—Flight Management System).
The response to R970010 was received from Airservices Australia on 13 June 1997:

`I am writing to provide Airservices' response to Recommendation R970010 from the above report [An analysis of incidents involving air crew failing to comply with air traffic clearances: June- August 1996].

Prior to the release of the report, Airservices' had been conducting independent reviews of many of the issues raised in your report. These reviews have included functional workshops in which BASI representatives have participated. The most recent workshop was convened for the purpose of discussing STARS, particularly in the Sydney environment.
As a result of these reviews, the following has occurred:

1. Airservices is currently progressing the development of an East Coast traffic management plan. The concept involves strategic and tactical planning to meter aircraft into Terminal areas and hence to place less reliance on vectoring in that airspace.

2. Prior to commencing any proposed vectoring, Air Traffic Control are required to advise the pilot of any expectation to resume the transition phase of a STAR. A requirement to resume a STAR can only be exercised during the transition phase.

3. Airservices STARS are designed in accordance with the Air Traffic Services STARS policy document which in turn states that they must be designed in accordance with ICAO specifications. The Operational Policy Branch of Air Traffic Services has undertaken a program to standardise STAR design locally and in the Asia-Pacific forum.

4. Phraseologies were the subject of a specific workshop in 1996 involving representation from the industry, CASA and the Australia Defence Force. This workshop recommended the adoption of ICAO standard phraseologies to the maximum extent possible. Where ICAO was silent on the issue the situation was to be resolved with international best practice, Australian specific phrases or plain language. Recommended phraseologies resulting from this forum have been incorporated into the AIP/MATS amendments effective 14 August 1997.

5. The Air Traffic Services STAR design document requires STARs to be developed in consultation with all users which includes ATS service providers and those flying the procedures. The intent of this consultation is to:
. ensure that operators are familiar with the development program;
. provide an opportunity for users to add value to STARs;
. determine pilot/operator acceptance; and
. ensure FMS compatibility where applicable.

As part of the development process, STARS are "flown" in an approved airline simulator to confirm that the proposed STAR is both flyable, and acceptable for the aircraft type(s) used on that sector. This simulation normally includes FMS equipped operations.
Airservices will continue to review the issues raised in your report to ensure the continued safety health of the Australian air traffic service system.'
The following recommendation, reference R970011, was issued to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority on 31 January 1997 and stated:

The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation recommends that the Civil Aviation Safety Authority require all international RPT AOC holders to include comprehensive route briefings in their General Operations Manual and require their aircrew to review comprehensive route briefing material prior to each flight to Australia.
The response to R970011 was received from the Civil Aviation Safety Authority on 24 April 1997:

"I refer to BASI Investigation Report "An Analysis of Incidents Involving Aircrew Failing to Comply with Air Traffic Clearances—June to August 1996: which incorporates Recommendation R970011. The recommendation is that CASA require all international RPT AOC holders to include comprehensive route briefings in their General Operations Manual and require their aircrew to review comprehensive route briefing material prior to each flight to Australia. Our response is as follows:

Holders of international AOCs are required to comply with the provisions of the Civil Aviation Act, Regulations and Orders. Taken together, CAR 218 (Route qualifications of pilot in command of a regular public transport aircraft), CAR 233 (Responsibility of pilot in command before flight) and CAR 239 (Planning of flight by pilot in command) clearly require flight crews to be familiar with Australian procedures. It is also a condition of the AOC that operations be conducted in accordance with the requirements and procedures published in AIP.

CASA does not believe that the analysis presented in the report justifies the implementation of recommendation R970011 at this time. Such a requirement would be difficult to police and is open to wide interpretation as to the acceptability of individual route briefings. We will monitor pilot briefing material during foreign operator ramp checks, and keep the situation under review. However, if the recommendations of R970010 are implemented by Airservices Australia, CASA believes that the incidence of failure to comply will markedly reduce.'
BASI considers those recommendations 970010 and 970011 as being CLOSED—ACCEPTED, which means that the Bureau accepts the response without qualification.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: Is the Civil Aviation Safety Authority responsible for reviewing the operation of the airline industry with respect to the safety of persons on the ground; if not, will he ensure that the responsibility is included in the authority's charter.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) is responsible for enforcing legislative provisions which have been created, inter alia, for protecting the safety of persons on the ground.

These include section 20A of the Civil Aviation Act 1988, which prohibits careless or reckless aircraft operations that would endanger the life, person or property of another person. Other examples are Civil Aviation Regulation (CAR)155 relating to acrobatic flight, CAR 156 relating to flying over public gatherings and CAR 157 relating to low flying.

subdebateinfo.title: Medicare Offices: Quality of Service Survey
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 189)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Aged Care, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2832 (Hansard , 25 May 1998, page 3664), did his Department or the Health Insurance Commission undertake an inquiry, review or otherwise consider the quality of service provided by Medicare customer service centres in New South Wales; if so, (a) what inquiries, reviews or consideration and (b) was the Hurstville Medicare Office included; if so, (i) when was it undertaken and (ii) what was the result.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) Each year the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) undertakes customer service research to guide the organisation towards its ongoing goal of greater customer focus. The research looks at the service the HIC provides in the administration of its main programs. The research includes questions on the overall quality of service provided by Medicare Offices, but does not include questions about the quality of service in specific Medicare Offices.
(b) The research was conducted door-to-door on a random basis in both metropolitan and rural areas nationally. Participants are not asked which Medicare Office they usually attend.

(2) The closure of metropolitan Medicare Offices did increase customer traffic in neighbouring Medicare Offices that remained open. talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Aged Care, upon notice, on 24 November 1998 :

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a call by the NSW Farmers' Association for Medicare provider numbers to be allocated to match population numbers in specific geographic areas; if so, (a) what is the feasibility of the proposal and (b) will he introduce it.
(2) Is it fact that existing incentives to attract medical practitioners to rural areas have failed.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Government has acknowledged this and other health policies proposed by the NSW Farmers' Association including the proposal to link provider numbers to specific geographical areas as a mechanism to address the maldistribution of the medical workforce.

There is a shortage of doctors particularly General Practitioners in rural and remote areas of Australia. While approximately 30% of Australia's population live outside capital cities and metropolitan areas, only 23% of General Practitioners work in rural and remote areas. Maldistribution of the medical workforce is not unique to Australia, in that it is a worldwide problem.

The Government has carefully considered geographical control of provider numbers and believes that there are more effective means of addressing workforce maldistribution. Rather than force doctors to work in rural areas, it is preferable to provide incentives such as rural locum relief for rural practitioners, scholarships, the funding of regional clinical schools and the encouragement of rural students into medical schools. Research has shown that these students are more likely to return to rural areas upon completion of training. Furthermore, there may be constitutional barriers preventing the Commonwealth from taking such action.

Australia already produces enough medical graduates to meet the country's overall requirements and introduction of section 19AA of the Health Insurance Act (1973), known as the "provider number legislation", ensures a high standard of health care delivery by requiring all doctors to obtain postgraduate qualifications. The introduction of "area of need" access to Medicare rebates for temporary resident doctors and overseas-trained doctors has provided rural communities and public hospitals with an increased supply of medical practitioners and is an effective and longer-term solution for rural communities.
(2) Existing incentives to attract medical practitioners to rural and remote areas have not failed.

The General Practice Rural Incentives Program (GPRIP) which began in 1993 sought to improve the recruitment and retention of GPs in rural and remote communities. This program is now known as the Rural and Remote General Practice Program (RRGPP) and was devolved to Commonwealth funded Rural Workforce Agencies in July 1998.
The GPRIP and now RRGPP programs have provided support to the rural and remote medical workforce and the communities they service in the following ways:
- During the period 1992/93 to 1996/97 the overall number of GPs and `other medical practitioners' practising in small rural centres in Australia grew by 7%, from 867 to 925;

- The Continuous Medical Education/Locum Grants component demonstrated that the grants were well regarded as an effective mechanism to support rural and remote GPs and succeeded, in some states, in establishing locum support networks where previously none existed; and

- Relocation grants as a mechanism to support rural doctors are available, with an increase from 50 to 113 grants approved during the period 1994/95-1996/97. Around 30% of those who received the funds say they would not have moved without it. Around 60-70% say that it helped and will make a difference to the length of time they stay.

Retention is an important objective of this program and these support mechanisms for practising rural GPs. This objective has been met with available data demonstrating a reduction in drop out rates and an increase in medical practitioners entering rural and remote practice.
Other rural incentives and support mechanisms are provided within the General Practice Strategy and include:
- the Better Practice Program;
- RACGP training program;
- Rural Division Coordinating Units; and
- the Rural Divisions of General Practice.
In addition to this, the Government has sought to increase the training and supply of Australian medical students via:

- an increase in the level of rural health training for students of medicine within Australia. Coordination and support of this strategy is also recognised by many state and territory health departments. The University of Newcastle has demonstrated a commitment to this strategy through the introduction of a compulsory rural placement within their course structure;

- the development of a clinical school at Wagga Wagga, New South Wales, for medical students undertaking training through the University of New South Wales. Through exposure to rural health care settings with appropriate levels of support, it is felt that this initiative will equip Australian medical graduates with both the skills and interest in working in rural areas;

- the Commonwealth has agreed to provide funding to establish a medical school at the James Cook University, Townsville. The geographical location of this university offers an opportunity for medical students from rural or indigenous backgrounds or students wishing to gain experience in rural health, to undertake a clinical placement in a rural setting. The school will offer students appropriate levels of support during their placement, using clinical advisers and medical practitioners who possess skills and experience in rural health care;

- the Government is supporting university initiatives to increase numbers of students from rural communities and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander backgrounds in Medicine. This focus is particularly evident in the admission profile at the University of Newcastle, Monash University, The University of Queensland and The University of Tasmania. The Government recognises that medical students from rural or remote communities are more likely to return to these communities to practice medicine upon completion of their training when compared to students from urban backgrounds;
- John Flynn Scholarships to provide medical students with rural experience during their undergraduate training; and

- as part of its measures to enhance the training and experience of young doctors in their early postgraduate years, the Medical Training Review Panel (MTRP) has recommended that all doctors in their first two years post-gradu ation have at least one term of experience in a community setting. My department is working with the States and Territories to implement this recommendation. As many as possible of these rotations will be in rural areas.

. preparation of Australian Standards by the Standards Association of Australia (SAA) and by bodies accredited by the Standards Accreditation Board of the SAA;

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 2 December 1998:

question.para: What was the cost of (a) production and (b) distribution of his Department's publication entitled Vetaffairs and how many persons were employed in its production in each year from 1993.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Veterans' Affairs; Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Background

Since 1998, considerable changes have been made to Vetaffairs. Previously it was published 11 times a year but distributed to only approximately 40,000 veterans per issue, largely through intermediary organisations such as ex-service organisations and nursing homes, with just a few thousand delivered to individuals who had asked to go on the mailing list. In 1998, it was decided the number of issues of Vetaffairs would be reduced to four per year. This allowed the distribution for each issue to be increased to over 400,000 veterans and war widows and widowers in receipt of a payment and/or a health benefit through my Department. The much larger printing runs of Vetaffairs mean some economies of scale have been achieved regarding printing costs, but because the distribution method now has become more sophisticated with direct mailings to over 400,000 households, overall costs are not easily compared to previous arrangements.

In the recent Veteran Satisfaction Survey, 93% of respondents indicated that they were satisfied or very satisfied with the most recent issue of Vetaffairs. The majority of respondents said they read all or most of the paper (over 86%) and rated the various aspects of the paper as good or very good.
(a) and (b)

Complete itemised cost data dating back to 1993 is unavailable due to the joint recording and consolidation of Vetaffairs costs at various times with a range of other departmental printing and publication costs. However, analysis of 1996/97 information provides a reliable "per issue" cost expenditure estimate which would also provide a good indication of "per issue" production and distribution costs in earlier years. This analysis indicates that each monthly issue of Vetaffairs cost just under $24,000, amounting to $260,000 for 11 issues in a calendar year.

After the change to the new arrangements in 1998, three issues of Vetaffairs were published in March, June and November. Production costs for the first two expanded issues totalled about $144,000 and distribution costs were about $440,000 (plus a small amount of postage incurred by my Department's State Offices sending copies on request to individuals/organisations). This equates to a total of about $292,000 per issue, or around 73 cents per veteran household including postage. Invoices on hand for the third issue in November 1998 indicate that production and distribution costs will again be of this magnitude for this and future issues.

A full-time editor at the Public Affairs Officer Grade 3 level works on the publication and there is some input (about three days per issue) from my Department's graphic designer together with some general administrative support. Similar arrangements have applied in earlier years. Printing and distribution are carried out under contract by a printing firm and a mail house.
