subdebateinfo.title: Convention on the Elimination of all forms of Racial Discrimination
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 289)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 December 1998:

question.para: (1) What progress has been made in (a) withdrawing or (b) modifying the declaration that Australia made on 30 September 1975 in ratifying the 1966 International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination.
(2) What other countries have made a similar declaration.
(3) On what dates and in what terms did they make their declarations

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) On ratification of the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination on 30 September 1975, Australia made the following declaration:

"The Government of Australia . . . . . . .declares that Australia is not at present in a position specifically to treat as offences all the matters covered by article 4(a) of the Convention. Acts of the kind there mentioned are punishable only to the extent provided by the existing criminal law dealing with such matters as the maintenance of public order, public mischief, assault, riot, criminal libel, conspiracy and attempts. It is the intention of the Australian Government, at the first suitable moment, to seek from Parliament legislation specifically implementing the terms of article 4 (a)."

The declaration was last considered in 1995. Withdrawal of the declaration is not possible at this stage. Article 4 (a) of the Convention contemplates the enactment of criminal offences for racial hatred and incitement to racial discrimination. As the Racial Hatred Act 1995 contains only a civil prohibition on such conduct it does not fulfil Australia's obligations under Article 4 (a) and therefore is not sufficient to allow Australia to withdraw its declaration. At this point only the ACT Discrimination Act 1991 makes serious racial vilification a criminal offence.

(2) I refer you to the UN Publication "Multilateral Treaties Deposited with the Secretary-General: status as at 31 December 1997". An updated version of this publication is available on the internet: http://www.un.org/depts/treaty
(3) See (2) above

subdebateinfo.title: Covenant on Civil and Political Rights
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 290)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 December 1998:

question.para: (1) What progress has been made in (a) withdrawing or (b) modifying the reservations and declarations that Australia made on 13 August 1980 in ratifying the 1966 International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
(2) What other countries have made similar reservations or declarations.
(3) On what dates and in what terms did they make their reservations or declarations

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) When Australia lodged its instrument of ratification on 13 August, 1980, a number of declarations and reservations were lodged. On 6 November 1984 Australia withdrew the reservations and declarations made upon ratification with regard to Articles 2 and 50, 10, 14, 17, 19, 20 and 5
Australia has maintained the following reservations:
Article 10

"In relation to paragraph 2 (a) the principle of segregation is accepted as an objective to be achieved progressively. In relation to paragraph 2(b) and 3 (second sentence) the obligation to segregate is accepted only to the extent that such segregation is considered by the responsible authorities to be beneficial to the juveniles or adults concerned."
Article 14

"Australia makes the reservation that the provision of compensation for miscarriage of justice in the circumstances contemplated in paragraph 6 of article 14 may be by administrative procedures rather than pursuant to specific legal provision."
Article 20

"Australia interprets the rights provided for by article 19, 21 and 22 as consistent with article 20; accordingly, the Commonwealth and the constituent States, having legislated with respect to the subject matter of the article in matters of practical concern in the interest of public order (ordre public), the right is reserved not to introduce any further legislative provision on these matters."
Declaration

"Australia has a federal constitutional system in which legislative, executive and judicial powers are shared or distributed between the Commonwealth and the constituent States. The implementation of the treaty throughout Australia will be effected by the Commonwealth, State and Territory authorities having regard to their respective constitutional powers and arrangements concerning their exercise."

The question of withdrawing or modifying the reservations made when Australia ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights is considered every year when Australia's National Action Plan on human rights is updated. Paragraph (c) of the National Action Plan requires Australia to indicate human rights treaty reservations we intend to remove.

In relation to the reservation to Articles 10 (2) and (3) of the Covenant, due to Australia's demo graphic and geographical features it is difficult to achieve the total segregration of accused and convicted prisoners, and children or juvenile prisoners from adult prisoners. Furthermore the Australian Government remains convinced that it is appropriate to allow the responsible authorities discretion to determine whether it is beneficial for a child or juvenile to be imprisoned with adults. However the Government is committed to achieving the goal of separation of accused and convicted prisoners and has taken some steps in this direction. For example, under the Standard Guidelines for Corrections in Australia, accused persons awaiting trial are separated from convicted persons as far as practicable and remandees are accorded different treatment from convicted persons. There are no present intentions to withdraw or modify Australia's reservations.

In relation to the reservation to Article 14 of the Covenant, there are administrative procedures available in all Australian jurisdictions to provide compensation for miscarriages of justice in the circumstances envisaged in paragraph 6 of this Article. The reason for maintaining Australia's reservation to Article 14 was the requirement in paragraph 6 of that article for statutory compensation in cases of miscarriage of justice, whereas in Australia the procedures for granting compensation do not necessarily have a statutory basis. Accordingly, the reservation to Article 14 is still considered appropriate.

The reservation to Article 20 reflects Australia's strong tradition of freedom of expression. Where there is a clear necessity to restrict that right in the public interest or for foreign policy reasons, the Federal Government will take the necessary legislative action. The Government has acted to prohibit or suppress propaganda in the past and has passed the Racial Hatred Act 1995. The Racial Hatred Act 1995 strikes a balance between the right to freedom of expression and rights of all persons to live free from fear of violence and racial hatred. Accordingly, there are no present intentions to withdraw Australia's reservation to Article 20.

(2) I refer you to the UN Publication "Multilateral Treaties Deposited with the Secretary-General: status as at 31 December 1997". An updated version of this publication is available on the internet: http://www.un.org/depts/treaty
(3) See (2) above.

subdebateinfo.title: Convention on the Rights of the Child
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 291)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 December 1998:

question.para: (1) What progress has been made in (a) withdrawing or (b) modifying the reservation that Australia made on 17 December 1990 in ratifying the 1989 Convention on the Rights of the Child.
(2) What other countries have made similar declarations.
(3) On what dates and in what terms did they make their declarations.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Upon ratification of the Convention on the Rights of the Child on 17 December 1990, Australia made the following reservation:

"Australia accepts the general principles of article 37. In relation to the second sentence of paragraph (c), the obligation to separate children from adults in prison is accepted only to the extent that such imprisonment is considered by the responsible authorities to be feasible and consistent with the obligation that children be able to maintain contact with their families, having regard to the geography and demography of Australia. Australia therefore ratifies the Convention to the extent that it is unable to comply with the obligation imposed by article 37 (c)."

The question of withdrawing or modifying the reservation made when Australia ratified the Convention on the Rights of the Child is considered every year when Australia's National Action Plan on human rights is updated. In relation to the reservation to Article 37 (1) of the Convention, Australia's demographic and geographical features often make it difficult to achieve the total segregration of children or juvenile prisoners from adult prisoners. However, the Government is considering the recommendation made by the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, in its 1998 Report on the Convention on the Rights of the Child, that the Government withdraw the reservation to Article 37 (3) of the Convention. A Government response is currently being formulated.

(2) I refer you to the UN Publication "Multilateral Treaties Deposited with the Secretary-General: status as at 31 December 1997". An updated version of this publication is available on the internet: http://www.un.org/depts/treaty
(3) See (2) above.

subdebateinfo.title: Convention for the Protection of Civilian Persons in Times of War
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 292)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 December 1998:

question.para: (1) What progress has been made in (a) withdrawing or (b) modifying the declarations that Australia made (i) on 14 October 1958 in ratifying the 1949 Geneva Convention relative to the Protec tion of Civilian Persons in Times of War and (ii) on 21 December 1991 in ratifying the 1977 Protocol I Additional to the 1949 Conventions and relating to the Protection of Victims of International Armed Conflict.
(2) What other countries have made similar declarations.
(3) On what dates and in what terms did they make their declarations.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The declaration made when Australia ratified the Geneva Convention relative to the Protection of Civilian Persons in Times of War has not since been considered. No progress has been made on withdrawing or modifying this declaration, and there is no present intention to withdraw or modify it.

The declarations made when Australia ratified Protocol 1 Additional to the Geneva Conventions were last considered prior to ratification on 21 June 1991. No progress has been made in withdrawing or modifying these declarations. The declarations were considered appropriate at the time of ratification, and are still considered appropriate, as the circumstances ruling at that time have not materially altered. Accordingly there is no present intention to withdraw or modify them.

(2) The parameters of this question are too broad to be answered in this forum. I refer you to the ICRC web site which has the full text of all State Party reservations and declarations in its international humanitarian law database: www.ICRC.org/UNICC/ICRCnews.NSF/DocInde x/Site_Tree?OpenDocument
(3) See 2 above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 3 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Do parts 5 and 6 of the Airports Act 1996 require (a) aircraft noise, (b) air quality of emissions from aircraft in flight and (c) associated health issues to be included in the factors considered when developing an environmental strategy for an airport.

(2) Did he advise the Sydney Airport Corporation (SAC) through their recently appointed consultants, Sinclair Knight Mutch Pty Ltd, to exclude (a) aircraft noise, (b) air quality of emissions from aircraft in flight and (c) associated health issues when preparing an environmental strategy for Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport; if so (i) will he provide details of correspondence between the SAC, the consultants and other persons relating to the advice and (ii) does he have the power to have the factors excluded from consideration; if so, under what authority.
(3) If he did not provide the advice referred to in part (2), which of the factors referred to in part (1) will be included in the environmental strategy for Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport.
(4) If a factor referred to in part (1) is not at present included in the environmental strategy, will he ensure that it is included.
(5) Will the environmental strategy be more effective if it includes the factors referred to in part (1).
(6) Is he able to say what obligations parts 5 and 6 of the Airports Act 1996 impose on the preparation of the environmental strategy.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Part 5 of the Airports Act 1996 regulates land use, planning and building control at leased Federal airports. It requires the preparation of an airport master plan, major development plans for significant airport developments and regulates building activities at airport sites. Part 6 of the Airports Act 1996 requires each airport lessee company to prepare a final environment strategy for an airport. A final environment strategy is a draft environment strategy that has been approved by the Minister. The matters which must be set out in a final environment strategy are set out in Division 2 of Part 6 of the Airports Act 1996. None of these relate specifically to aircraft noise, air quality of emissions from aircraft in flight and associated health issues (see (6) below).

(2) My Department has provided advice to Sydney Airport Corporation Ltd (SACL) indicating that issues such as the noise and emissions generated by aircraft in flight fall outside the scope of the Draft Environment Strategy (DES). These matters are canvassed separately in The Long Term Operating Plan for Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport and Associated Airspace and the Proponent's Statement for the Sydney Airport Long Term Operating Plan, and currently fall within the responsibilities of other agencies including the Department of Transport and Regional Services and Airservices Australia. A copy of the correspondence can be made available to the member.

(6) Division 2 of Part 6 of the Airports Act 1996 specifies the matters that must be set out in a draft or final environment strategy. Part 3 of the Airports (Environment Protection) Regulations sets out additional matters which must be specified in the strategy. The airport lessee company is obliged to specify its objectives for the environmental management of the airport. In particular, it must address impacts of on-site airport operations and include specific measures, and time frames for completion of those measures, which it proposes to adopt to prevent, control or reduce environmental impacts.

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport: Long Tern Operating Plan
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 297)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 3 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Is it a fact that modes 6A and 8 outlined in the Long Term Operating Plan for Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport have not been implemented; if not, why not.

(2) Will the combination of increased aircraft noise and north easterly winds during summer greatly exacerbate noise to the north of the airport, especially over the electoral division of Lowe, if the modes are not implemented before 1999.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Mode 6A was not outlined in the Long Term Operating Plan. Neither mode 6A nor mode 8 have been implemented because relevant safety and operational clearances are not yet available.

(2) Seasonal variations in prevailing winds suggest an increased likelihood of northerly winds during summer in the Sydney area. These conditions result in the use of runway modes that involve departing jet aircraft passing over the electoral division of Lowe.

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport: Instrument Landing Systems
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 298)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 3 December 1998:

question.para: Is it a fact that implementation of the instrument landing system for the east-west runway of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport would greatly improve the operation and use of the runway thus ensuring compliance with the Long Term Operating Plan; if so, has he expedited implementation of the system; if not why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Airservices Australia has recently provided me with a report on a study conducted by an independ ent consultant on the benefits and costs of installing an instrument landing system on runway 25 at Sydney Airport. The consultant's report concludes that the installation of the ILS together with a runway threshold relocation " could provide a significant increase in relative terms of the Mode [Mode 5]. . .". Mode 5 is an important noise sharing mode. The report will be placed on the agenda for the next meeting of the Sydney Airport Community Forum to allow community representatives to discuss the merits of the proposal before a final decision is made.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 3 December 1998:

question.para: Following his announcement of a new chairperson for the Sydney Airport Community Forum, will the Forum meet before Christmas 1998 to urgently address the concerns of those Sydney residents who are being unfairly exposed to aircraft noise.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: I am pleased that Dr Brendan Nelson MP has agreed to chair the Sydney Airport Community Forum (SACF). Dr Nelson hosted an informal meeting of the SACF on 16 December 1998. All members of the Forum were invited to attend. I am advised that Mr Murphy discussed issues of concern with Dr Nelson.
The next formal meeting of the Forum is due to be held on 26 February 1999.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 8 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Have adequate steps been taken to monitor the appearance of prion-based diseases in meat products fed to poultry in Australia.
(2) Does regular testing for the spontaneous appearance of prion-based diseases in meat fed to poultry occur in Australia; if so, what are the details.
(3) What assurances can be given that prion-based diseases will not occur in Australia.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) There is no evidence of clinical prion diseases of animals (including poultry) in Australia. This status is monitored through a national surveillance program that has been implemented to meet international requirements for countries claiming to be free of transmissible spongiform encephalopathy diseases in their cattle and sheep. Strict quarantine protocols are in place to protect Australia from prion diseases of animals.

(2) As indicated, a national surveillance program is in place involving the examination of a set number of sheep and cattle brains, collected from animals with suspect clinical signs. As part of the program, general awareness activities as well as specialist training were instituted. Because Australia is free of clinical prion disease of animals, no specific testing is undertaken for such diseases in meat fed to poultry.

(3) Existing strict quarantine provisions are designed to prevent the introduction of prion diseases to Australia through imported products. In the event of a spontaneous case occurring the national surveillance program and routine diagnostic sampling of Australia's animal populations should ensure the early detection and elimination, by implementation of an agreed national plan (AUSVETPLAN) of any individual animals that might be affected.

subdebateinfo.title: Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme: Contributors
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 312)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 December 1998:

question.para: (1) How many contributors to the Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme exited from the scheme (a) between 28 September and 26 October 1998 and (b) since 27 October 1998.

(2) How many contributors in each category referred to in part (1) (a) preserved their lump sum member benefit in the scheme, (b) withdrew their member benefit as a lump sum or (c) withdrew their member benefit and subsequently repaid it into the scheme.
(3) What was the (a) actual investment performance of the scheme from 1 July to 30 September 1998 and (b) applicable exit rate for each month since 1 July 1998.

(4) Before the Opposition raised the matter in Parliament, what measures did the scheme's Board of Trustees put in place to inform members that a negative exit rate had been adopted and to advise them of their options.
(5) What measures has he put in place to ensure that recent problems do not recur.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Veterans' Affairs; Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) 411 contributors exited from the Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme (MSBS) between 28 September 1998 and 26 October 1998.
(b) 559 contributors exited from 27 October 1998 to 14 December 1998.

(2) (a) 17 members who exited between 28 September 1998 and 26 October 1998 preserved their member benefit; and 38 members who exited between 27 October 1998 and 14 December 1998 preserved their member benefit.

23 members who exited between 28 September 1998 and 26 October 1998 and 30 members who exited between 27 October 1998 and 14 December 1998 have not yet submitted a benefit application. If an application is not received within 3 months of discharge the benefits will automatically be preserved.

(b) 371 members who exited between 28 September 1998 and 26 October 1998 withdrew their member benefit as a lump sum; and 491 members who exited between 27 October 1998 and 14 December 1998 withdrew their member benefit as a lump sum.
(c) 2 members withdrew their member benefit and subsequently repaid it into the scheme.
(3) (a) The investment performance of the scheme from 1 July 1998 to 30 September 1998 was—1.1%.
(b) Applicable exit rates since 1 July 1998 were:

(4) Through the Board's communications advisory group, a number of different approaches were adopted to inform members of the new exit rate policy adopted from 1 July 1998 and the MSB Board's decision on 30 October 1998 to amend the calculation program for preserved benefits. The approaches taken were:
. details of the MSB Board's exit rate policy placed on the ComSuper website;

. members advised of changes to the exit rate policy and the possibility of negative returns in the annual report to members, which was enclosed with each member's information package despatched in October. This package also included a booklet on the MSB Fund investment policy;

. on 15 October 1998 an article appeared in the Army News and in November 1998 a similar article appeared in the Air Force News. The article was also submitted for inclusion in the summer edition of Sea Talk;

. from 30 October 1998 members who contacted the ComSuper advisory unit were advised of the implications of a negative exit rate and the option to preserve their benefit until a more favourable exit rate was declared;

. on 16 November 1998 letters were prepared to all members who had discharged on and after 28 September 1998 and before 30 October 1998 who had been affected by the negative exit rate to inform them that they had an option of preserving their benefit until a more favourable rate applied. Members who discharged from 30 October 1998 and were affected by the negative exit rate were contacted by ComSuper prior to payment being made to make sure they were fully informed of the implications of withdrawing their benefit; and
. in early November an article was submitted for inclusion in the next issue of The Key, a publication of the Defence Personnel Executive. It appeared in the December issue.

(5) I have asked the Department of Defence to look at ways of enhancing direct communication with members on superannuation issues. The Board and the Department have advised me that at the December meeting a communications strategy for 1999 was endorsed. The strategy is aimed at improving communications with members on superannuation matters of both immediate and longer term effects. It will be put in place in consultation with the Department of Defence and will include such new initiatives as:
. a regular chat column in the Service newspapers;
. having a team of suitably experienced people who can visit work locations to discuss issues with members on a face-to-face basis; and
. developing a new interactive website with the ability to interrogate and develop options to suit a member's retirement needs.

I have also been advised that a notice has been distributed to all Defence locations that deal with discharging members stressing the importance of members obtaining advice on their superannuation entitlements immediately before discharge.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment Services, upon notice, on 9 December 1998:

question.para: Has he introduced evaluation measures to ensure that funds allocated under tender documents and business plans for Job Network providers are being spent in line with the providers' commitments; if so, (a) what measures, (b) when will the measures commence and finish and (c) will the results be made public; if so, when; if not, what accountability measures are in place to safeguard the spending of public funds.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) As Job Network members are primarily contracted to place job seekers into jobs, the ultimate measure of their success is the extent to which they place job seekers into jobs. The performance of Job Network members in the current contract period will be a consideration in assessing tenders for the next contract period, should those members choose to tender.

The Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business has in place a Job Network monitoring strategy which has a number of components. It includes the assessment of the performance of each Job Network member against their allocated level of business, as well as monitoring of client complaints and compliance with statutory legal requirements.

Job Network members are required, through the Employment Services Contract 1998-99 to provide the Department with access to their premises, financial accounts and records, employees and job seekers' records. This is obviously necessary as part of the Department's evaluation and monitoring of providers. The Contract is the legal agreement between the Commonwealth and Job Network members which protects the interests of the Commonwealth.

A complaint mechanism also exists under the Contract. Job seekers, employers, apprentices and trainees are able to raise any concerns with Job Network members, or with the Department if there is no resolution of the concern. The Contract requires Job Network members to maintain a register of complaints which must be accessible by the Department.

In August 1998 the then Minister announced the provision of Market Development Funding for Job Network members providing Job Matching services. Provision of this funding was dependent on the Commonwealth's acceptance of an appropriate Market Development Business Plan from the Job Network member. Departmental contract managers monitor progress by Job Network members against these business plans and funding must be acquitted at the end of the contract period.
(b) Job Network contract monitoring measures are in operation for the duration of the Contract.

Market Development Funding was available from 1 October 1998, with the final payment to be made in March 1999. Recipients of Market Development Funding are to provide the Department with an acquittal of expenditure by 31 March 1999.

(c) The results of Departmental monitoring activities for individual Job Network members are commercial in confidence and as such will not be made public. The Job Network monitoring strategy, as outlined above, addresses the Department's obligations under the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997, which provides a framework for the proper management of public money.
The Department meets its obligations under the Act through the Employment Services Contract 1998-99.
